title: Noctes ambrosianae,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: I paid nae attention to them, but left them to amuse theirsels Clavers and Giraffe, that s the twa grews Fang, the terrier and Guile and Rover, collies at least they ca Rover a collie, though he s gotten a cross o some outlandish bluid, and he belangs to the young gentle man at Thirlstane, but he s a great freen o our Guile s, and often pays him a visit.

title: The works of Professor Wilson of the University of Edinburgh,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: I paid nae attention to them, but left them to amuse theirsels — Claverse and Giraffe, that's the twa grews — Fang, the terrier — and Guile and Eover, collies — at least they ca' Rover a collie, though he's gotten a cross o' some outlandish braid, and he belangs to the young gentleman  at Thirlstane, but he's a great freen o' our Guile's, and aften pays him a visit.

title: Noctes Ambrosianæ.
author: Wilson, John
snippet: I paid nae attention to them, but left them to amuse theirsels — Clavers and Giraffe, that's the twa grews — Fang, the terrier — and Guile and Hover, collies — at least they ca' Rover a collie, though he's gotten a cross o' some outlandish bluid, and he belangs to the young gentleman  at Thirlstane, but he's a great freen 6' our Guile's, and often pays him a visit.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: Whether I had been frightened %t the machinery when very young, of which, I think, I have Bome shadowy remembrance — whether I had heard the stories of the Miller of Thirlstane, and similar molendinar tragedies, I cannot tell ; but not even recollections of the Lass of Patie's Mill, or the Miller of Mansfield, or he who dwelt on the river Dee,' have ever got over my inclination to connect gloom with % mill, especially when the sun is setting.

title: The Edinburgh tales.
author: Johnstone, C. I.
snippet: I say, Warrock, what sort of gear is it fair and bonny, like the maidens of Torwoodlse, or black but comely, like the proud Thirlstane  dames ?'

title: The Edinburgh tales.
author: Johnstone, C. I.
snippet: " Lauderdale waxed very Avroth, and sputtered and churned venom for a full minute ; but Lady Edgelaw, and other folks of the Edgelaw, were his old country neighbours,  in a sense, though miles apart both from Dunbar and Thirlstane ; and there was, besides, an ancient obligation anent hiding some of the race at the steading of Edgelaw, in the former troubles of the kingdom and maybe, too, as it is sagaciously said in the vernacular strain, though somewhat savouring  of profanity, ' The De'il's no aye so ill as he's called ;' for Lauderdale nichered a loud horse-laxigh, as if at his own passion,

title: The Edinburgh tales.
author: Johnstone, C. I.
snippet: All Scotland shall hear of it, and answer too ! What care we for their headings and hangings, when driven to extremities like this ? So go tell the excommunicate  apostate at Thirlstane that, Simon Sloan, as ye are one of his Malignant kind.

title: The Edinburgh tales.
author: Johnstone, C. I.
snippet: of Edgelaw ! I'm for Thirlstane, Simon

title: The Edinburgh tales.
author: Johnstone, C. I.
snippet: Spare neither horseflesh  nor man's strength ; and, as ye ride, raise the Waters ! Make saddle my own nag ; I '11 ower to Thirlstane, to the Wolf's den.'

title: The Edinburgh tales.
author: Johnstone, C. I.
snippet: " ' He is off to Edinburgh last Monday morning, to crave from the Privy Council a deed of gift of Redheugh's lands,' continued the farmer of the Mains 'your owngreat- grandsire he was, Mr. Elliot, and a savoury Christian in his generation ; but there will be words about that ; for there are as greedy gleds before him yonder as himself off, after attending ane of their Pandemonium  Councils against us and ours, over at Thirlstane, where the hallowed rest of the blessed Sabbath was spent in cards and dice, drinking and damning, and blasphemies sit to have split the roof of the Castle, and sunk it fathoms deep in the earth.'

title: The Edinburgh tales.
author: Johnstone, C. I.
snippet: " Robin, slow as'his pace was, in dandering from farmstead to farmstead, was the only post and mail of those days, unless when a laird or a lord, like Thirlstane or Torwood- lee, or him of the Black Barony, or the malignant persecutor, Sir Marmaduke Winram,  might send off one of their house-varlets with a special budget on some of their godless errands of harriment and cruel oppression of the Lord's people.

title: A journal of a residence ... in London; including excursions through various parts of England; and a short tour in France and Scotland; in the years 1823 and 1824
author: Wheaton, Nathaniel Sheldon.
snippet: HumeCastle, on the top of a hill; and Thirlstane, a seat ofthe Earlof Lauderdale, embosomed in a narrow valley, were among thefew objects of attraction which occurred ; the country generally presenting little to the eye except barren moors, peatbogs, and naked, swelling hills.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: This was John Scott of Thirlstane, whom Jamesrewarded with an addition to his paternalcoat-of-arms, with a bunch of spears forthe crest, and the motto, Ready aye Ready.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Tlris was John Scott ofThirlstane, whom James rewarded with an addition to his paternal coat-of-amis, with a bunch ofspears for the crest, and the motto, " Ready, ayeReady."'James, finding himself thus generally thwartedand deserted by the nobility, returned to Edinburgh, dishonoured before his people, and in thedeepest dejection of mind.

title: Reminiscences of Yarrow. Edited and annotated by ... Professor Veitch, LL.D. Illustrated by Tom Scott ... Second edition
author: Russell, James
snippet: And a similarextract, of date 27th June 1653, bears : " Upon thehumble desire of Patrick Scott of Thirlstane, tohave ane brig across the Yarrow, the magistratesof Peebles ordain that all in the town who havehorses shall send the same for a day, to carry limefor the said brig, under the penalty of 40 shillings."

title: Secretar. Founded on the story of the Casket Letters
author: Beatty, W.
snippet: Howbeit we gat to Thirlstane without misadventure of anysort, and that long before sunset, for whilk I was right glad,having small fancy to ride in the darkling ower the lonesomehills, with sic a daft companion as Gregory had shewn himself.

title: Secretar. Founded on the story of the Casket Letters
author: Beatty, W.
snippet: him he was himself again, and beguiled the way from there toTollishill and Thirlstane, where we were to lodge the night, withmany a wild tale and tuneful ballant.
